articles.title: China exceeds Australia's yearly emissions in just 12 days exposing Labor's 'futile' renewables push
articles.author: Patrick Hannaford
articles.summary: China emits more carbon every 12 days than Australia does in an entire year. Australia's per capita emissions have decreased by 24.3% since 2004, but China's have more than doubled, increasing by 109%. Australia's share of global emissions is now 1%, down from 1.3%. China is responsible for 73% of the global emissions increase since 2004.

articles.title: Climate risks reshape North Carolina's housing market
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Rising insurance costs and climate risks are reshaping North Carolina's real estate market. Realtors explain to WRAL News what home buyers should know.       .   "Climate risks reshape North Carolina’s housing market"

articles.title: We Did It!
articles.author: danielmedinaprints
articles.summary: 2025 is on pace to brake the streak of each year being hotter than the last. However, it's still the second hottest year in recorded history. Daniel is on Instagram, Twitter and Facebook. He is also the creator of the "Fallow Me" campaign.

articles.title: Cancún hurricane preparedness gets a hard post-Wilma audit
articles.author: Ian Hayden Parker
articles.summary: Two decades after Wilma, officials tout Cancún hurricane preparedness, pointing to drainage work and new protocols. We check what changed and what still matters in Cancun after the hurricane Wilma and find out what still needs to be done.

articles.title: Antarctica's September weather driving current hot windy conditions
articles.author: Hawke'S Bay
articles.summary: Antarctica's warm weather in September is driving the gale force winds and hot temperatures being felt across New Zealand this week. Temperatures could reach nearly 30 degrees in Hawke's Bay on Thursday. The region is under a strong wind watch as fire crews work to try and contain a huge bush fire near Porangahau. Meteorologist Chris Brandolino is helping Fire and Emergency with their fire risk forecasting.

articles.title: Overshooting 1.5C climate target 'inevitable': UN boss
articles.summary: Overshooting the 1.5C climate target is inevitable, says UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres. The 2015 Paris climate accords aimed to limit global warming to well below 2C above pre-industrial (1850-1900) levels. Guterre's remarks come ahead of the COP30 climate summit in Brazil next month. The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has said emissions must fall 60 percent by 2035.

articles.title: Pakistan's Path to a $3 Trillion Economy Hindered by Climate Change and Population Growth, Says Aurangzeb
articles.author: Daniel Foster
articles.summary: Pakistan's aspirations to achieve a $3 trillion economy are threatened by population growth and climate change. Multinational corporations are leaving the country or significantly reducing their operations due to these macro-economic challenges. The recent smog crisis in Lahore and devastating floods are stark reminders of this escalating threat.

articles.title: Kayser: Calmer weather with warming temperatures ahead
articles.author: DJ Kayser
articles.summary: The Great Lakes are running above average. Lake Superior is about 4.8 degrees above the 30-year average. There will be frosty starts Thursday and Friday morning, but a gradual warming trend will continue into the weekend. There's a chance of rain into early next week, but models are mixed.

articles.title: Unprecedented Heat Wave Puts Millions at Risk
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Queensland is experiencing a severe heatwave. The Bureau of Meteorology issues warnings of extreme and severe heatwaves. Brisbane is forecast to reach a maximum of 34 degrees today, while Ipswich will peak at 38 degrees. Warwick is expected to hit 36 degrees, and Toowoomba can expect 34 degrees. The rising temperatures have triggered fire warnings across large parts of Queensland.

articles.title: UN chief says overshooting 1.5°C climate target is 'inevitable'
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres says it's impossible to limit global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels in the short term, but it's possible before the end of the century. Paris climate accords aimed to limit warming to well below 2°C, and 1°C if possible. UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has said emissions must fall 60% by 2035, from 2019 levels, to reach the target.

articles.title: Queensland heatwave to last into next week
articles.summary: Temperatures in large parts of Queensland are forecast to soar from today, triggering fire warnings by authorities. The weather is expected to trigger a rise in the fire risk.    in the state. The Queensland Fire Service has issued a fire warning for the whole state.

articles.title: Ministry of Agriculture ramps up preparation efforts ahead of Tropical Storm Melissa
articles.summary: The Ministry of Agriculture has activated its disaster preparedness protocols in anticipation of the approaching weather system. Rural Agricultural Development Authority (RADA) teams have been deployed across Jamaica to support farmers in securing their crops, livestock and infrastructure. Fisheries officers from the National Fisheries Authority (NFA) have been dispatched to fishing beaches, especially along the south coast, to ensure vessels are secured and evacuation plans are in place.

articles.title: Overshooting 1.5C climate target 'inevitable': UN chief
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres says it's impossible to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels in the short term. The 2015 Paris climate accords aimed to limit warming to well below 2C. The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has said emissions must fall 60 percent by 2035 to reach the target.

articles.title: The Lingering Storm: 20 Years After Katrina – Stories of Hope and Action
articles.summary: 'The Lingering Storm: Climate Change, Displacement, and Action' is being presented by CIR, Capital B, Hip Hop Caucus, and Texas Observer on September 10, 2025. Two decades after Hurricane Katrina, we gather to reflect, reckon, and look forward.

articles.title: STATEMENT: CARICOM Declaration on the Tenth Anniversary of the Paris Agreement and COP 30
articles.author: Malaika
articles.summary: Adopted Thursday, 16 October 2025 by the Forty-First Inter-Sessional Meeting of the Conference of Heads. Reaffirms that climate change presents a fundamental threat to humanity and planetary habitability. Caribbean small island and low lying coastal developing states (SIDS) are disproportionately burdened by its impacts. Member States play a critical role as stewards of rich, unique, and biologically diverse marine and terrestrial ecosystems.

articles.title: Record-Breaking CO2 Rise Shows The Amazon Is Faltering - Yet The Satellite That Spotted This ...
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: A new satellite analysis shows that CO2 rose faster in 2024 than in any year since records began. This is far faster than scientists had expected.    - The Conversation, Menafn and The Conversation.  - Menafna and The Converse.

articles.title: Overshooting 1.5C climate target 'inevitable'
articles.author: afp
articles.summary: Overshooting the 1.5C climate target is "inevitable", says UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres. The 2015 Paris climate accords aimed to limit global warming to well below 2C above pre-industrial (1850-1900) levels. The COP30 climate summit is taking place in Brazil next month.

articles.title: Revived US Climate-Disaster Database Shows Record $101 Billion in Losses in First Half of Year
articles.summary: On May 7, 2025, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's billion-dollar disasters program ended. Climate Central relaunched the database under Adam Smith using NOAA's methodology. The database costs about $300,000 annually under the Trump administration. The relaunch makes data available to insurers, policy makers, meteorologists and citizens.

articles.title: Costliest First 6 Months From Climate Disasters Ever, 2025 Data Shows
articles.author: Bias Comparison
articles.summary: On May 7, 2025, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's billion-dollar disasters program ended. Climate Central relaunched the database under Adam Smith using NOAA's methodology. The database costs about $300,000 annually under the Trump administration. The relaunch makes data available to insurers, policy makers, meteorologists and citizens.

articles.title: How a climate adaptation 'shortfall' is being felt in northern Australia
articles.author: Charlie McLean
articles.summary: The extreme heat in northern Australia is making climate adaptation more difficult. The most common strategies to reduce urban heat centre on "green" and "blue" spaces. Neither the City of Karratha nor the other local governments in the wider Pilbara region could provide a specific climate adaptation plan.

articles.title: Florida Farms Lose $171.1M per Year to Natural Hazards
articles.author: Trace One
articles.summary: High grocery prices have been a defining economic story in recent years. Natural disasters, such as droughts, floods, and hurricanes, affect the nation's agricultural output. In April 2025, a devastating weather system massively flooded corn, rice, soybean, and wheat crops in eastern Arkansas, affecting 31% of agricultural acreage in the region and inflicting an estimated $99 million worth of damage. Hurricane Helene hit North Carolina in late September 2024, prompting the U.S. Department of Agriculture to grant $221.2 million in federal disaster assistance block grants to help the industry rebuild.

articles.title: Aussies urged to join the big Bug Hunt for science
articles.author: illawarramercury.com.au
articles.summary: Aussies have overwhelmingly backed a project to count native birds. They are now being asked to look under the trees.       in order to find out what is under the tree that needs to be removed to count birds.  in the project.

articles.title: Urgent Call to Double International Food Aid: A Global Hunger Challenge
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Winners of the World Food Prize urge the global community to double international food aid to meet the rising malnutrition needs of about 2 billion people. UN World Food Program reports a 40% reduction by 2025. Major donors, such as the U.S., have slashed contributions, impacting food-aid-dependent nations like the Democratic Republic of Congo and Haiti.

articles.title: How The World Meteorological Organization Lies To You—Using Your Taxes
articles.author: Dr. Matthew Wielicki
articles.summary: The WMO's latest Greenhouse Gas Bulletin reports record CO2 levels in 2024 (423.9 ppm) and the largest annual increase ever (3.5 ppm from 2023). The bulletin attributes this almost entirely to human emissions. The bulletin completely omits a bombshell Nature paper, which claims rivers emit 2.0 PgC/year of CO2.

articles.title: Schools, Colleges Closed on October 23 in SPSR Nellore District
articles.author: Pathri Rajasekhar
articles.summary: The cyclonic system over the Bay of Bengal is expected to bring heavy to very heavy rains from October 23 to 25. The district administrations in Nellore, Tirupati and Prakasam have stepped up their vigil, issued public safety alerts and activated emergency response systems. The fisheries department issued specific alerts for fishermen and aquaculture units. Chittoor collector Sumit Kumar announced October 23 a holiday for schools.

articles.title: The Amount of Climate Change Misinformation That In-the-Tank Scientific Journals Have Peddled Over the Last Decade Is Scandalous
articles.author: Thomas J Shepstone
articles.summary: Doug Sheridan and Bjorn Lomborg are critical of the climate change scam. They argue that the media hype over climate change is damaging public trust in the scientific community. They are also critical of Elon Musk's purchase of Twitter and his influence in the social networking site.

articles.title: Flooding and droughts drove them from their homes. Now they're seeking a safe haven in ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: There is higher than average migration growth to the US from Guatemala, Bangladesh, Senegal and other countries hit by climate disasters, according to the data analysis.   Â      .   in the U.S. because of climate disasters.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa Projected to Become our Next Major Hurricane
articles.author: Bias Comparison
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Melissa is moving west-northwest at 7 mph with 50 mph winds. Forecasters warn of heavy rain, strong winds, tropical-storm-force gusts up to 105 miles, and dangerous surf threatening the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Jamaica. The chance of direct U.S. impacts is low but cannot be ruled out.

articles.title: Global warming pushing planet to the brink
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres warned that global warming is pushing the planet to the brink. He urged countries to implement disaster warning systems to protect people against extreme weather. The last ten years have been the hottest in history. 60 percent of countries have already introduced Early Warning Systems. Guterre wants all countries to have them in place by 2027.

articles.title: Australia's largest citizen science project the Aussie Bird Count returns for its 12th year
articles.summary: The Aussie Bird Count returns for its 12th year. It's the largest citizen science project in Australia. It was started by a group of Australian citizens. It is funded by donations from people interested in bird-watching and other citizen science projects.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'Oh, the HORROR! Climate Change to Make More Rain in the Sahara Desert', By ANTHONY WATTS
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: By the second half of the 21st century, the Sahara Desert could see 75% more precipitation than its historical norm. Under extreme climate conditions, rainfall is expected to increase in southeastern and south-central Africa. The southwestern region will be drier, with an anticipated 5% decline in precipitation.

articles.title: Above average water temperatures on the Great Lakes concerning scientists
articles.summary: There are above average water temperatures on the Great Lakes, which is concerning scientists.    Share this link with someone you know. For confidential support call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 1-800-273-8255 or visit http://www.suicidepreventionlifeline.org/.

articles.title: Nairobi Among Regions Set to Experience Heavy Rainfall Over the Next Seven Days
articles.author: David Wafula
articles.summary: Kenya Meteorological Department has issued a weather alert warning of heavy rainfall across several parts of the country, including Nairobi, over the next week. Rainfall is expected to intensify to more than 30mm within 24 hours. The rains will spread to the Highlands East of the Rift Valley and the South-Eastern Lowlands from Thursday, October 23, 2025, to October 30, 2025.

articles.title: Free Teen Climate Event at Buttonwood Park Zoo You'll Want to Share
articles.author: Nancy Hall
articles.summary: Buttonwood Park Zoo in New Bedford will host a free Youth Climate Summit on Saturday, November 15, from 10 AM to 2 PM. It's a day of hands-on workshops and speakers for young environmentalists. Breakfast and lunch are included in the day-long event. Pre-registration is required.

articles.title: Climate science and early warnings key to saving lives (UNOG - United Nations Office at Geneva)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: António Guterres says that no country is safe from the impacts of extreme weather and that early-warning systems should be accessible to all.    .   i   in the abstract.  in this is an abstract. In the text, the abstract is the text.

articles.title: Ted Nordhaus: Why I Stopped Being a Climate Catastrophist
articles.author: Eric Worrall
articles.summary: Ted Nordhaus no longer believes in climate change as an imminent catastrophe. Eric Worrall shares his thoughts on the topic with Tyler Norris. Eric applauds Ted Nordhaus for coming forward and admitting he no longer thinks climate change is an imminent disaster. Eric hopes others will follow his example.

articles.title: International Day for Climate Action, 2025
articles.author: External Source
articles.summary: The Earth is already over 1.3 °C warmer than pre-industrial times. 2014 was the hottest year ever recorded. Extreme weather displaced over 800,000 people last year. We are failing the 1.5 °C goal unless we act now. October 24 is the International Day for Climate Action.

articles.title: Nigeria Validates National Plan To Tackle Climate Change
articles.author: Lantana Nasir
articles.summary: Nigeria has validated its National Adaptation Plan (NAP). The document serves as a strategic blueprint to build national resilience against the growing threats posed by climate change. It is being developed with support from the Green Climate Fund (GCF). It builds on 13 thematic areas previously identified in Nigeria's Nationaladaptation Strategy & Plan of Action (NASPA). A key component of the NAP process is the Climate Risk and Vulnerability Assessment (CRVA).

articles.title: America first, but not America only: Sinodinos says
articles.author: Zac de Silva
articles.summary: Australia is being warned to avoid relying solely on its alliance with the United States. The Indo Pacific region is becoming more contested and Australia should not rely on the U.S. as the only reliable ally. Australia is a member of the UN Security Council.

articles.title: UN chief seeks urgent action against global warming, urges countries to "fight misinformation" on climate
articles.author: ANI
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres warned that "global warming is pushing our planet to the brink" and called for "urgent global action" to expand early-warning systems and deliver on climate finance. He also urged countries to fight against "mis- and disinformation, online harassment, and greenwashing" in his address at an event on Early Warnings for All during the Extraordinary Session of the World Meteorological Congress.

articles.title: Overshooting 1.5C climate target ‘inevitable': UN chief
articles.author: Gulf News
articles.summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres says efforts to cap global warming at 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial levels would fail in the short term. Next month's COP30 climate summit will take place in Brazil.       .

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa could strengthen as it moves slowly
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: Melissa's cloud bands are affecting the Dominican Republic, particularly along the southern coast. The storm's outer bands could bring prolonged rain through Sunday across much of the country. Authorities and relief agencies urge the public to stay alert and avoid rivers and flood-prone areas.

articles.title: Welfare cuts are fueling the rise of the far right globally, the UN finds
articles.author: Ana Nicolaci Da Costa
articles.summary: Welfare cuts are fueling the rise of the far right globally, the UN finds, as it has done in the U.S. and Europe. It's also a problem in Africa and in the Middle East as it's also happening in Russia and China.

articles.title: Climate Facts: World's coral reefs facing unprecedented dieback, study finds
articles.author: Janefrances Chibundu
articles.summary: The Cable's quick climate facts will help demystify the concepts of climate change. A new report says the world has entered a new reality, as global warming will soon exceed 1.5°C. In every country, human-enabled climate change added more extreme hot days, according to a new study. The study added that the world is heading towards 2.6°C of warming.

articles.title: UN warns: Global warming is pushing the planet to the brink
articles.author: News.bg
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres warned that global warming is pushing the planet to the brink. He urged countries to introduce disaster warning systems to protect people from extreme weather conditions.
